subject: LAT
title: Beg. Latin I
info: Latin is the genesis of modern Romance languages and is foundational to science, law, religion, education, and philosophy. The study of Latin sharpens the mind and fuels the development of critical thinking and problem-solving skills. The Latin introductory sequence (1001/1002) will prepare you to read authentic, historical texts and will ground you in solid grammar and vocabulary. Developing your acumen in this essential ancient language will open the door to a wide range of classical, medieval, and Renaissance authors, playwrights, and poets.

subject: LAT
title: Beg. Latin II
info:
Continuation of Latin 1001. More complex constructions, including participles, clauses, indirect discourse. Some reading of adapted passages from ancient texts.

prereq: Grade of at least C- or S in 1001 or instr consent

subject: LAT
title: Beg Lat II, Trans
info: Continuation of basic grammar/vocabulary, practice reading/writing. Latin readings, Roman legends.

subject: LAT
title: Sel Lat Lit, Trans
info: Prose/poetry. Historical/literary background.

subject: LAT
title: Intermediate Latin Prose
info:
Introduction to Latin prose authors of 1st centuries BCE/CE. Readings of continuous passages of unadapted Latin texts (history, speeches, letters). Review of grammar/vocabulary as needed. Some discussion of major themes/issues in Roman culture as illustrated by texts.

prereq: Grade of at least C- or S in 1002 or 5001 or instr consent

subject: LAT
title: Intermediate Latin Poetry
info: Introduction to Roman epic poetry. Readings of selections from Vergil's Aeneid. Quantitative meter and poetic devices. Discussion of major themes and issues as developed in Vergil's poetry.

subject: LAT
title: Reading Latin Prose
info: Introduction to reading Latin prose. Selections from Roman authors. Review of grammar/syntax. Follow-up course to intensive Latin or review for students returning to reading Latin after time lapse.

subject: LAT
title: Intens. Lat. Rec.
info: Drills and composition exercises. Students must also register for 3111 when taking this course.

subject: LAT
title: Latin AP Credit
info: Prereq score of [3 or 4 or 5] on [AP Vergil or AP Latin Literature] exam.

subject: LAT
title: Intermediate Latin Poetry
info: Readings in Latin poetry. Introduction to Latin Meter. Vergil and Catullus/Ovid offered in alternate years.

subject: LAT
title: Adv Und Lat: Hist
info: Roman history as the Romans wrote it;  selections from Livy, Sallust, Tacitus, or Ammianus.

subject: LAT
title: Adv Und Lat: Lit
info: Selections from expository Latin literature (essays, epistles, monographs).

subject: LAT
title: Adv Und Lat Oratory
info: One or more appropriate authors studied each semester.

subject: LAT
title: Adv Und Lat: Epic
info: One or more appropriate authors studied each semester.

subject: LAT
title: Adv Und Lat: Lyric
info: One or more appropriate authors studied each semester.

subject: LAT
title: Adv Und Lat: Drama
info: One or more appropriate authors studied each semester.

subject: LAT
title: Adv Und Lat:Satire & the Novel
info: One or more authors.

subject: LAT
title: Directed Studies
info:
Guided individual reading or study.

prereq: instr consent and dept consent

subject: LAT
title: Directed Research
info:
Research project using documents and other sources from the ancient world. Students select project in consultation with a faculty member who directs the research and writing.
Students enrolling in this Directed Research course will complete the University's common Directed Study/Research contract with the faculty mentor/evaluator. 

Prereq: [Greek-Latin or Latin major], three 3xxx Latin courses

Students enrolling in this directed research course will complete the University's common Directed Research contract with the faculty mentor/evaluator. The Faculty member will ensure academic standards are upheld, including:
- the work proposed is at the appropriate level for the course, academic in nature, and the student will be involved intellectually in the project.
- the project scope is reasonable for one semester and the number of credits specified (42 hours of work per credit)
- the faculty mentor is qualified to serve in this role - assessment of student learning and grading criteria are clear and appropriate
- the student will be working in a respectful, inclusive environment.
The contract will include the learning objectives for the course, the methods that will be employed, and how assessment will be conducted by the faculty mentor. The contract must be approved by the DUGS/academic approver of the major before the student can register.

subject: LAT
title: Beginning Latin I
info: Graduate students will work in tandem with LAT 1001 and complete additional exercises from original readings in their chosen field of study (e.g., English, Music, History) to improve their abilities to read archival materials related to their discipline.

subject: LAT
title: Intensive Latin
info:
Covers material usually taught over two semesters.

prereq: Prev experience in another foreign language is desirable

subject: LAT
title: Int Latin Prose: Grad Research
info:
Introduction to Latin prose authors of 1st centuries BCE/CE. Readings of continuous passages of unadapted Latin texts (history, speeches, letters). Review of grammar/vocabulary as needed. Some discussion of major themes/issues in Roman culture as illustrated by texts.

prereq: [Grade of at least [C- or S] in [1002 or 5001] or instr consent]

subject: LAT
title: Int Latin Poetry Grad Research
info: Introduction to Roman epic poetry. Readings of selections from Vergil's Aeneid. Quantitative meter and poetic devices. Discussion of major themes and issues as developed in Vergil's poetry. Meets with 3004.

subject: LAT
title: Advanced Latin Poetry
info:
The primary material for this course will be a selection of readings from three or more different
Latin poets connected by genre (e.g. epic, dramatic, lyric), theme (e.g. heroism and the hero,
the body, the good life), period (e.g. Augustan, late Antique), or the like. Primary readings and
critical approach will vary from year to year, making the course repeatable. Some modern
secondary reading will be assigned to provide a basis for discussion and a model for student
written work.

prereq: [3004 or equiv], at least two yrs of college level Latin. Contact the Classical & Near Eastern Religions & Cultures Department with any questions.

subject: LAT
title: Advanced Latin Prose
info:
The primary material for this course will be a selection of readings from three or more different
Latin prose authors connected by genre (e.g. historical writing, philosophy, religious texts),
theme (e.g. Epicureanism and Stoicism, Christian apologetics, grammarians), period (e.g.
Republican, Late Imperial), or the like. Primary readings and critical approach will vary from
year to year, making the course repeatable. Some modern secondary reading will be assigned
to provide a basis for discussion and a model for student written work.

prereq: [LAT 3004 or equiv], at least two yrs of college level Latin. Contact the Classical & Near Eastern Religions & Cultures department (CNRC) with any questions.

subject: LAT
title: Lat Lit: History
info: One or more authors.

subject: LAT
title: Lat Lit: Epistles
info: One or more authors.

subject: LAT
title: Lat Lit: Oratory
info: One or more authors.

subject: LAT
title: Lat Lit: Epic
info: One or more authors.

subject: LAT
title: Lat Lit: Poetry
info: One or more authors.

subject: LAT
title: Lat Lit: Dramatists
info: One or more authors.

subject: LAT
title: Lat Lit: Satire and the Novel
info: One or more authors.

subject: LAT
title: Lat Legal Texts
info: One or more authors.

subject: LAT
title: Lit: Religious Text
info: Reading/discussion of religious texts from Latin antiquity, such as Varro's Antiquitates Divinae, Cicero's De natura deorum, Apuleius's Metamorphoses, or Christian writers (Tertullian, Cyprian, Lactantius, Jerome, Augustine).

subject: LAT
title: Lat of Late Antiq
info: Pagan/Christian Latin literature selected from authors of 3rd to 6th centuries AD. Topics specified in Class Schedule.

subject: LAT
title: Medieval Latin
info: Literature from 6th to 15th centuries. Authors/genres vary. Topics specified in Class Schedule.

subject: LAT
title: Lat Prose Comp
info:
Latin grammar, syntax, diction, and prose style. Graduated exercises in prose composition.

prereq: Grad student or instr consent

subject: LAT
title: Text Criticism
info:
Theory/practice. Elements of paleography and manuscript study. Tools for analyzing a textual apparatus. Constructing a critical edition of a literary text.

prereq: Grad student or instr consent

subject: LAT
title: Epigraphy
info:
Practical/theoretical introduction to Latin epigraphy (study/interpretation of inscriptions). Readings/discussion of epigraphic texts. Their value as historical documents, as evidence for development of Latin language, and as literary texts.

prereq: Grad student or instr consent

subject: LAT
title: Latin Paleography
info: Analysis of various hands used in manuscripts of Latin authors, with attention to date/provenance. Transmission of ancient Latin literature.

subject: LAT
title: Intro: Hist-Comp Greek & Latin
info:
Historical/comparative grammar of Greek and Latin from proto-Indo-European origins to classical norms.

prereq: Two yrs college [Greek or Latin] or instr consent

subject: LAT
title: History of Latin
info: Reading/analysis of documents illustrating stylistic registers/evolution of Latin language, from its earliest attestations through Middle Ages.

subject: LAT
title: Sight Reading
info:
Practice in reading Latin texts at sight.

prereq: Enrolled in a grad program in Department of Classical/Near Eastern Studies

subject: LAT
title: Directed Studies
info:
Guided individual reading or study.

prereq: instr consent, dept consent

subject: LAT
title: Directed Research
info:
Guided research on original topic chosen by student.

prereq: Grad student or instr consent

subject: LAT
title: Directed Instr
info:
Supervised teaching internship.

prereq: Grad student or instr consent

subject: LAT
title: Readings in Latin Prose
info: Reading/discussion of Latin prose texts.

subject: LAT
title: Latin Texts
info:
Students attend 3xxx Latin courses.  Supplementary work at discretion of instructor.

prereq: 3111 or dept consent; not for students in dept of Classical and Nr East Studies

subject: LAT
title: Readings in Latin Verse
info:
Reading/discussion of Latin poetic texts.

prereq: Advanced grad student

subject: LAT
title: Latin Lit. I
info: Extensive readings in variety of works from republican and early Augustan period.

subject: LAT
title: Latin Lit. II
info: Variety of works from Augustan and imperial periods.

subject: LAT
title: Late Antique Latin
info:
Latin literature of 3rd to 6th centuries A.D., including Ammianus and Augustine.

prereq: instr consent, dept consent

subject: LAT
title: Readings in Latin Texts
info:
Reading/discussion of literary or documentary texts from Roman antiquity. Topics may include subjects that draw on various sources, genres, or methods.

prereq: Advanced grad student

subject: LAT
title: Seminar
info: Topics in Latin literature examined in depth. Emphasizes current scholarship, original student research.
